'''''Pleurotus''''' is a [[genus]] of [[Gill (mushroom)|gill]]ed [[mushroom]]s which includes one of the most widely eaten mushrooms, ''[[Pleurotus ostreatus|P. ostreatus]]''.  Species of ''Pleurotus'' may be called '''oyster''', '''abalone''', or '''tree mushrooms''', and are some of the most commonly [[Fungiculture|cultivated]] [[edible mushroom]]s in the world.<ref name=chang/>  ''Pleurotus'' fungi have been used in [[mycoremediation]] of pollutants such as [[petroleum]] and [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]]s.<ref name=stamets/><ref name=cohen02/>

==Description==
The caps may be laterally attached (with no stem).  If there is a stem, it is normally eccentric and the gills are [[decurrent]] along it.  The term ''[[Pleurotoid fungi|pleurotoid]]'' is used for mushrooms having this general shape.<ref name=Bon/>

The spores are smooth and elongated (described as "cylindrical").  Where [[hypha]]e meet, they are joined by [[clamp connection]]s.  ''Pleurotus'' is not considered to be a [[bracket fungus]], and most of the species are [[monomitic]] (with a soft consistency).  However, remarkably, ''[[Pleurotus dryinus]]'' can sometimes be [[dimitic]], meaning that it has additional skeletal hyphae, which give it a tougher consistency like bracket fungi.<ref name=Funga/>

==Ecology==
''Pleurotus'' fungi are found in both [[tropical climate|tropical]] and [[temperateness|temperate]] climates throughout the world.<ref name=chang/>  Most species of ''Pleurotus'' are [[wood-decay fungus|white-rot fungi]] on [[hardwood]] trees, although some also decay [[softwood|conifer wood]].<ref name=cohen02/>  [[Pleurotus eryngii]] is unusual in its association with [[herbaceous plant]]s, and ''P. tuber-regium'' produces underground [[Sclerotium|sclerotia]].<ref name=hib94/>  In addition to being [[saprotroph]]ic, all species of ''Pleurotus'' are also [[Nematophagous fungus|nematophagous]], catching [[nematode]]s by paralyzing them with a toxin.<ref name=barron87/><ref name=thorn00/>

==Cuisine==
Oyster mushrooms are popular for cooking, torn up instead of sliced, especially in [[stir fry]] or [[sauté]], because they are consistently thin, and so will cook more evenly than uncut mushrooms of other types.<ref>[http://www.mssf.org/cookbook/oyster.html Oyster Mushroom]</ref> They are often used in [[vegetarian cuisine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lengskitchen.blogspot.my/2012/10/deep-fried-oyster-mushroom.html|title=Kitchen Chaos: Deep Fried Oyster Mushroom|website=lengskitchen.blogspot.my|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref>

==Taxonomy==
[[File:Pleurotus pulmonarius LC0228.jpg|thumb|right|''P. pulmonarius'', [[Sweden]]]]

The classification of species within the genus ''Pleurotus'' is difficult due to high [[phenotype|phenotypic]] variability across wide geographic ranges, geographic overlap of species, and on going evolution and [[speciation]].  Early [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] efforts placed the oyster mushrooms within ''[[Agaricus]]'' (''Agaricus ostreatus'' [[Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin|Jacq.]] 1774).  [[Paul Kummer]] defined the genus ''Pleurotus'' in 1871; since then, the genus has been narrowed with species moving to other genera such as ''[[Favolaschia]]'', ''[[Hohenbuehelia]]'', ''[[Lentinus]]'', ''[[Marasmiellus]]'', ''[[Omphalotus]]'', ''[[Panellus]]'', ''[[Pleurocybella]]'', and ''[[Resupinatus]]''.  See Singer (1986)<ref name=Singer1986/> for an example of ''Pleurotus'' [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomy]] based on [[Morphology (biology)|morphological]] characteristics.

==Phylogeny==
More recently, molecular [[phylogenetics]] has been utilized to determine [[genetics|genetic]] and [[evolution]]ary relationships between groups within the genus, delineating discrete [[clade]]s.<ref name=gonzalez/><ref name=pnas/><ref name=vil96/>  ''Pleurotus'', along with the closely related genus ''[[Hohenbuehelia]]'', has been shown to be [[monophyly|monophyletic]].<ref name=thorn00/>  Tests of cross-breeding viability between groups have been used to further define which groups are deserving of [[species]] rank, as opposed to [[subspecies]], [[variety (botany)|variety]], or [[Synonym (taxonomy)|synonymy]].  If two groups of morphologically distinct ''Pleurotus'' fungi are able to [[Hybrid (biology)|cross-breed]] and produce fertile offspring, they meet one definition of [[Species problem|species]].  These reproductively discrete groups, referred to as intersterility groups, have begun to be defined in ''Pleurotus''.<ref name=pnas/><ref name=utknox/>  Many binomial names used in literature are now being grouped together as [[species complex]]es using this technique, and may change.

===Phylogenetic species===
The following species list is organized according to 1. phylogenetic clade,<ref name=gonzalez/><ref name=vil96/> 2. intersterility group (group number in [[Roman numerals]]) or sub-clade,<ref name=pnas/><ref name=utknox/> and then 3. any older binomial names that have been found to be closely related, reproductively compatible, or synonymous, although they may no longer be taxonomically valid. This list is likely to be incomplete.

 [[File:Pleurotus populinus 13996.jpg|thumb|right|''P. populinus'', [[Pennsylvania]], USA]]
 [[File:Pleurotusjf.JPG|thumb|Pleurotus mushrooms production at the Agricultural Science and Technology School, [[Science City of Muñoz#Schools|Science City of Muñoz]], [[Philippines]]]]
*''P. ostreatus'' clade<ref name=vil96/>
** I. ''[[Pleurotus ostreatus|P. ostreatus]]'' (oyster or pearl oyster mushroom) – North America and northern Eurasia<ref name=pnas/>
*** ''[[Pleurotus florida|P. florida]]''<ref name=gonzalez/>
** II. ''[[Pleurotus pulmonarius|P. pulmonarius]]'' (phoenix or Indian oyster mushroom) – North America, Eurasia, and Australasia<ref name=vil96/><ref name=nz/>
*** ''[[Pleurotus columbinus|P. columbinus]]''<ref name=gonzalez/>
*** ''[[Pleurotus sapidus|P. sapidus]]''
** III. ''[[Pleurotus populinus|P. populinus]]'' – North America<ref name=pnas/>
** VI. ''[[Pleurotus eryngii|P. eryngii]]'' (king oyster mushroom) – Europe and the Middle East<ref name=pnas/>
*** ''[[Pleurotus ferulae|P. ferulae]]''
*** ''[[Pleurotus fossulatus|P. fossulatus]]'' – Afghanistan<ref name=pnas/>
*** ''[[Pleurotus nebrodensis|P. nebrodensis]]''<ref name=rod10/>
** XII. ''[[Pleurotus abieticola|P. abieticola]]'' – Asia<ref name=vil96/>
** XIII. ''[[Pleurotus albidus|P. albidus]]'' – Caribbean, Central America, South America<ref name=utknox/>
*''P. djamor-cornucopiae'' clade<ref name=vil96/> [[File:Spanish-mushrooms.jpg|thumb|right|''P. eryngii'', [[Spain]]]]
** IV. ''[[Pleurotus cornucopiae|P. cornucopiae]]'' (branched oyster mushroom) – Europe
*** ''[[Pleurotus citrinopileatus|P. citrinopileatus]]'' (golden oyster mushroom) – eastern Asia
*** ''[[Pleurotus euosmus|P. euosmus]]'' (tarragon oyster mushroom)
** V. ''[[Pleurotus djamor|P. djamor]]'' (The pink oyster mushroom) – pantropical
*** ''[[Pleurotus flabellatus|P. flabellatus]]''
*** ''[[Pleurotus salmoneo-stramineus|P. salmoneo-stramineus]]''
*** ''[[Pleurotus salmonicolor|P. salmonicolor]]''
** XI. ''[[Pleurotus opuntiae|P. opuntiae]]'' – North America,<ref name=vil96/> New Zealand<ref name=nz/>
** XVI. ''[[Pleurotus calyptratus|P. calyptratus]]''
* ''P. cystidiosus'' clade<ref name=gonzalez/><ref name=zerv04/> [[File:Limonenseitlinge (Pleurotus citrinopileatus) - 20100828.jpg|thumb|right|''P. citrinopileatus'']]
** VII. ''[[Pleurotus cystidiosus|P. cystidiosus]]'' (abalone mushroom) – Global
*** ''[[Pleurotus abalonus|P. abalonus]]'' – Taiwan
*** ''[[Pleurotus fuscosquamulosus|P. fuscosquamulosus]]'' – Africa, Europe
*** ''[[Pleurotus smithii|P. smithii]]'' – Mexico
** IX. ''[[Pleurotus dryinus|P. dryinus]]'' – North America, Europe, and New Zealand
* VIII. ''[[Lentinus levis]]'' – subtropical to tropical,<ref name=utknox/> moved to genus ''Lentinus''.<ref name=SF/>
* X. ''[[Pleurotus tuber-regium|P. tuber-regium]]'' (king tuber mushroom) – Africa, Asia, Australasia<ref name=hib94/><ref name=vil96/>
* XIV. ''[[Pleurotus australis|P. australis]]'' (brown oyster mushroom) – Australia and New Zealand<ref name=utknox/><ref name=nz/>
* XV. ''[[Pleurotus purpureo-olivaceus|P. purpureo-olivaceus]]'' – Australia and New Zealand<ref name=utknox/><ref name=nz/>
** ''[[Pleurotus rattenburyi|P. rattenburyi]]''

===Species of unclear relationship===
* ''[[Pleurotus gardneri|P. gardneri]]''
* ''[[Pleurotus parsonsii|P. parsonsii]]''<ref name=nz/>
* ''[[Pleurotus velatus|P. velatus]]''<ref name=nz/>

===Former species===
* ''[[Lentinus levis|P. levis]]'' was reclassified to the genus ''[[Lentinus]]''.
* ''[[Lentinus sajor-caju|P. sajor-caju]]'' was reclassified to the genus ''[[Lentinus]]''.
* ''[[Omphalotus nidiformis|P. nidiformis]]'' was reclassified to the genus ''[[Omphalotus]]'' in 1994.<ref name=miller/>
